thread.title: Iron ore price extends skid
thread.title_full: Iron ore price extends skid | Business Spectator

author: Daniel Palmer
title: Iron ore price extends skid
text:
The price of iron ore is steadily sinking toward the psychologically important $US50 a tonne mark as investors worry about growth in China.
At the end of the latest session, benchmark iron ore for immediate delivery to the port of Tianjin in China was trading at $US52.10 a tonne, down 0.7 per cent from $US52.50 a tonne in the prior session.
A streak of six straight red sessions has led the commodity to its lowest mark since the start of August, with concerns around demand from key customer China remaining at the forefront of traders' minds.
On Monday, economic growth in the region came in at its lowest level for six years, while industrial production slowed faster than the market had expected.
Commodity markets have been trending lower ever since given the importance of the Chinese economy to global demand, with most analysts maintaining their bearish bets.
“We ... still have a low of $US45 a tonne pencilled in for this year," Westpac senior economist Justin Smirk said, according to Bloomberg .
“While current prices are hurting the majors’ level of profits, their costs are still meaningfully below current prices, so they can continue to grow output. As such, there is no incentive for them to cut production and in fact, there is incentive to lift output to make up some of the revenue lost from lower prices.”
While the giants of the space are still making money, most smaller players are in the red below $US50 a tonne.
